title: 108_hr2874
content: The Act titled "Improving Access to Prescription Drug Benefits for Veterans Act of 2003" provides a prescription drug benefit for veterans. The "Improving Access to Prescription Drug Benefits for Veterans Act of 2003" establishes a prescription drug benefit program for eligible veterans enrolled in the Department health care system. Veterans can receive drugs and medicines prescribed by a licensed physician or health care professional outside the Department, with applicable premiums and copayments. The Act establishes a program for veterans to obtain prescriptions from non-Department providers, with premiums and copayments set by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary establishes copayment amounts for drugs and medicines provided to veterans, based on factors like generic or brand name, mail availability, and inclusion in the National Prescription Drug Formulary. The Secretary sets copayment amounts for prescriptions based on specific criteria and limits the maximum amount to the cost of furnishing the drugs. Receipts from copayments are deposited into the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Care Collections Fund. Health care professionals prescribing under this section are not considered agents or employees of the United States. The Secretary is required to maintain records of program costs. The Secretary is required to maintain records of program costs and implement a computerized patient profile system for participants in the prescription drug benefit program. The system will identify drug interactions, contraindicated drugs, best value treatment alternatives, and patient safety issues. Additionally, the Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the program's operation. The Secretary is mandated to maintain program records and implement a computerized patient profile system for participants in the prescription drug benefit program. The system will identify drug interactions, contraindicated drugs, best value treatment alternatives, and patient safety issues. An annual report to Congress on the program's operation is required, including details on the number of participants, new enrollees, program costs, and resources added to accommodate increased workloads. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out this section. Section 1722B of title 38, United States Code, regarding the prescription drug benefit, will become effective on the first day of the first month starting more than six months after the enactment of this Act.
